<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EDUCATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/26/college-applications-rise-elite-schools?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Ivy League Admissions Right Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A gif of the scene from the first Harry Potter movie where letters are pouring into the Dursley's house and Harry is struggling to grab them" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=283 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/UJS4fUKBaTc8o/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="A gif of the scene from the first Harry Potter movie where letters are pouring into the Dursley's house and Harry is struggling to grab them" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/UJS4fUKBaTc8o/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you thought a little school outside Boston liked touting its acceptance rate before...just wait for Class of 2025 stats. Applications for the upcoming fall semester <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-25/harvard-applications-surge-as-students-flock-to-biggest-names?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">are soaring</a> at elite institutions including Harvard (+42%), Yale (+38%), and NYU (+20%). Princeton is also up 15%. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">We stan the confidence</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Many schools are waiving standardized test requirements, and with fewer campus visits possible, students are gravitating toward trusted names. Plus, more applications → more potential acceptances → more opportunity for students to find the best price.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Undergrad admissions fell 13% last fall when colleges were presented with a different kind of contagious virus than they were used to. As vaccines roll out, prospective freshmen are expecting more normalcy this fall.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Submissions of the Common Application, a standardized app used by 900+ schools, </span><span><a href="https://www.insidehighered.com/admissions/article/2021/01/26/common-apps-new-data-show-overall-gains-applications-not-first?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">were up </a></span><span>10% as of Friday.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Not everyone's feeling the love</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Admissions <a href="https://www.highereddive.com/news/in-a-year-without-admissions-tests-elite-college-applications-balloon/593439/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">are down</a> for many regional or less-competitive schools. The State University of New York (SUNY) reported a 20% <a href="https://nypost.com/2021/01/25/suny-college-applications-plummet-20-percent-amid-covid-19/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">drop</a> in applications across its 64 campuses, particularly among its 30 community colleges. Applications across California's public university system are down 5%.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Common App administrators have also <a href="https://www.insidehighered.com/admissions/article/2021/01/26/common-apps-new-data-show-overall-gains-applications-not-first?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sounded</a> "alarm bells" for students from underrepresented populations. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Financial aid requests were down 11.4% as of Jan. 1, especially from high schools with a higher proportion of low-income, Black, or Hispanic students.   </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Applications from first-generation students are down 3%.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Is this a tipping point? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you stare in a mirror and say "college tuition is too high" three times, NYU Prof. Scott Galloway will appear. Last spring, he <a href="https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/05/scott-galloway-future-of-college.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">predicted</a> that, after a short-term dip, top-50 universities would undergo massive expansion...while the rest crumble.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">S&P Global agrees. The financial data firm <a href="https://www.highereddive.com/news/tracking-how-the-coronavirus-is-impacting-colleges/574858/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">issued</a> its fourth consecutive negative outlook for higher ed and said Covid-19 has exacerbated long-running problems around enrollment and revenue. It expects colleges that were previously struggling will fall further behind.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead</strong>...schools will be dealing with Covid in some capacity this fall. President Biden has called on federal agencies to set clearer guidance for reopening. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
C-SUITE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/27/roz-brewer-become-walgreens-ceo?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brewer Drops an O, Adds an E
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="SEATTLE, WA - MARCH 21: Starbucks Chief Operating Officer Roz Brewer spe..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zODYwL3N0YXJidWNrc19ob2xkc19hbm51YWxfc2guanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Stephen Brashear/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Rosalind “Roz” Brewer is stepping down as the COO of Starbucks and <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/26/starbucks-coo-roz-brewer-leaving-to-become-ceo-of-publicly-traded-company.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stepping up</a> as the CEO of Walgreens Boots Alliance. Her move is historic: Brewer will be the only Black woman running an S&P 500 company.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>As Brewer comes aboard in the spring, Walgreens CEO Stefano Pessina will move to executive chairman. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The CV: </strong>With Brewer, Walgreens is getting a retail vet with a reputation for investing in digital operations.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>She joined Starbucks after a five-year stint as the head of Walmart-owned Sam’s Club.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Before that, Brewer worked at Kimberly-Clark, the consumer goods giant. Fun fact: She started there as a chemist. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Brewer is a big loss for Starbucks, which was also forced to replace its CFO this month. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Brewer is entering a “plz fix” situation at Walgreens. With the coronavirus taking a sledgehammer to profits, the drugstore chain’s stock <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/walgreens-to-name-starbucks-executive-roz-brewer-as-ceo-11611700794?mod=hp_lead_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">fell 29.4%</a> last year...even as the broader Dow index gained 7.3%.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENVIRONMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/26/larry-fink-calls-netzero-economy-latest-ceo-letter?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Finking Green
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In his highly anticipated <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/26/business/dealbook/larry-fink-letter-blackrock-climate.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">annual letter</a> to CEOs, BlackRock chief Larry Fink called on businesses to reach net-zero emissions by 2050 and do their part to keep global warming in check. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fink can't technically make companies do anything. But like a parent who controls your allowance (in this case, almost $9 trillion in assets), he effectively can. And he has before:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In 2018, Fink wrote that profit isn't everything and companies need to think about their social impact.  </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In 2020, he called for </span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/14/investors-tough-passive-aggressive?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">prioritizing sustainability</a></span><span> and committed BlackRock to factoring climate risks into investment decisions. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Under the latest directive, BlackRock will create a "temperature alignment metric" to assess funds. Like calorie counts on a menu, the goal nudges investors into (environmentally) healthier decisions, DealBook writes.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>If companies don't take the carrot, they may meet Fink's stick. Last year, BlackRock put 191 businesses on a watch list and voted against 64 directors and 69 companies for climate-related reasons. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Fink would argue there's a better reason to play along: "The more your firms are seen to embrace the climate transition and the opportunities it brings, the more the market will reward your firms with higher valuations." </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The name of the investment game is (and always has been) diversification. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fundrise can potentially help you take your investment portfolio to higher levels than the high-rises and private real estate you’ll be investing in. Their <a href="https://fundrise.com/acq-plus/start?utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morningbrew&utm_campaign=primary-20210127&utm_content=all" target="_blank" class="link" data-saferedirecturl="https://www.google.com/url?q=https://fundrise.com/acq-plus/start?utm_medium%3Dnewsletter%26utm_source%3Dmorningbrew%26utm_campaign%3Dprimary-20210127%26utm_content%3Dall&source=gmail&ust=1611780459901000&usg=AFQjCNFqJEyDmKrs9UiA8C6XqfwWW57ScQ" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">intuitive and easy-to-use platform</a> enables you to <strong style="color:#000">closely monitor your investments and provides transparent communications around investment progress</strong>.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EARNINGS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/26/earnings-season-roundup-amex-johnson-johnson-vaccine-starbucks?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Overheard on Earnings Calls
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Earnings szn means two things: 1) a CEO's small talk skills being put to the test and 2) offhand remarks that reveal a lot about the current state of the business world. For example…</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">American Express </strong>CEO <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-american-express-results/amex-sees-consumer-travel-recovery-after-lower-spending-hits-profit-idUSKBN29V2A6?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Stephen Squeri</a> is bullish on leisure travel: "...As we get into this summer season, this June, July, August and September, you will see a rush for people to travel, especially air travel." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Johnson & Johnson</strong> CFO Joseph Wolk <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/johnson-johnson-profit-is-boosted-by-pharmaceuticals-business-11611666309?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">on the vaccine</a> the company is developing: "The fact that we do not require significant refrigeration beyond the norm, as well as being one shot, certainly does play into the label that some outside the company have called it a game-changer."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">GE </strong>CEO Larry Culp <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/2cce969c-80a7-4831-aadf-02c1394ac7ab?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">defending</a> his potential $47 million payout (in a few years, and only if company stock stays above $10 for at least 30 days): "I didn't take a salary last year once Covid hit. I think we all sacrificed." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Microsoft </strong>CEO Satya Nadella on <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/microsoft-msft-2q-earnings-report-2021-11611622268?mod=business_lead_pos4&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">its blockbuster quarter</a> buoyed by growing demand for video games and cloud computing: "What we have witnessed over the past year is the dawn of a second wave of digital transformation sweeping every company and every industry."</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BUSINESS BASICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/26/reader-question-stock-market-record-economy-tanking?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Reader Question: The Stock Market and the Economy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Weird stock market " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zODU2L3dlaXJkX3N0b2NrX21hcmtldC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Every Wednesday, we’re going to take a reader-submitted question about business and the economy and do our best to answer it. </em><a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/J0EH3zf3?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Ask your question here</em></a><em>. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">From Miles in Little Rock: </strong>Why is the stock market at a record while the economy is tanking? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The Brew’s answer: </strong>Hi Miles, it can definitely be disorienting to see the stock market soaring to all-time highs while millions of Americans are out of work because of the pandemic. Here are four possible explanations for the split screen we’re seeing on Wall Street and Main Street.</p>
<ol>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The stock market is future-looking. </strong></span><span>Stock prices reflect investors’ expectations of how companies will perform not now but later—for example, Tesla is worth more than many automakers </span><span><em>combined</em></span><span> because of its long-term growth potential. A roaring stock market means investors are betting on a healthy economic recovery.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The stock market is dominated by huge companies. </strong></span><span>And many of these huge companies, such as Amazon, Walmart, and Microsoft, </span><span><em>benefited</em></span><span> financially from the pandemic.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The economy isn’t as bad as we think. </strong></span><span>Some sectors of the economy, such as manufacturing and the housing market, are posting their best performances in more than a decade. </span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The stock market could also be wrong. </strong></span><span>A number of prominent investors say the stock market is all discombobulated because of the historic stimulus measures deployed by the government.  </span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000"></strong>Hope that helps! And feel free to <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/J0EH3zf3?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ask more questions here</a>. </p>

style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you thought a little school outside Boston liked touting its acceptance rate before...just wait for Class of 2025 stats. Applications for the upcoming fall semester \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-01-25/harvard-applications-surge-as-students-flock-to-biggest-names?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eare soaring\u003c/a\u003e at elite institutions including Harvard (+42%), Yale (+38%), and NYU (+20%). Princeton is also up 15%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWe stan the confidence\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMany schools are waiving standardized test requirements, and with fewer campus visits possible, students are gravitating toward trusted names. Plus, more applications → more potential acceptances → more opportunity for students to find the best price.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eUndergrad admissions fell 13% last fall when colleges were presented with a different kind of contagious virus than they were used to. As vaccines roll out, prospective freshmen are expecting more normalcy this fall.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSubmissions of the Common Application, a standardized app used by 900+ schools, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.insidehighered.com/admissions/article/2021/01/26/common-apps-new-data-show-overall-gains-applications-not-first?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewere up \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e10% as of Friday.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eNot everyone's feeling the love\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAdmissions \u003ca href=\"https://www.highereddive.com/news/in-a-year-without-admissions-tests-elite-college-applications-balloon/593439/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eare down\u003c/a\u003e for many regional or less-competitive schools. The State University of New York (SUNY) reported a 20% \u003ca href=\"https://nypost.com/2021/01/25/suny-college-applications-plummet-20-percent-amid-covid-19/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edrop\u003c/a\u003e in applications across its 64 campuses, particularly among its 30 community colleges. Applications across California's public university system are down 5%.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eCommon App administrators have also \u003ca href=\"https://www.insidehighered.com/admissions/article/2021/01/26/common-apps-new-data-show-overall-gains-applications-not-first?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esounded\u003c/a\u003e \"alarm bells\" for students from underrepresented populations. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFinancial aid requests were down 11.4% as of Jan. 1, especially from high schools with a higher proportion of low-income, Black, or Hispanic students.   \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eApplications from first-generation students are down 3%.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIs this a tipping point? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you stare in a mirror and say \"college tuition is too high\" three times, NYU Prof. Scott Galloway will appear. Last spring, he \u003ca href=\"https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/05/scott-galloway-future-of-college.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epredicted\u003c/a\u003e that, after a short-term dip, top-50 universities would undergo massive expansion...while the rest crumble.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eS\u0026P Global agrees. The financial data firm \u003ca href=\"https://www.highereddive.com/news/tracking-how-the-coronavirus-is-impacting-colleges/574858/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eissued\u003c/a\u003e its fourth consecutive negative outlook for higher ed and said Covid-19 has exacerbated long-running problems around enrollment and revenue. It expects colleges that were previously struggling will fall further behind.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead\u003c/strong\u003e...schools will be dealing with Covid in some capacity this fall. President Biden has called on federal agencies to set clearer guidance for reopening. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" Starbucks and \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/26/starbucks-coo-roz-brewer-leaving-to-become-ceo-of-publicly-traded-company.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" Her move is historic: Brewer will be the only Black woman running an S\u0026P 500 company.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs Brewer comes aboard in the spring, Walgreens CEO Stefano Pessina will move to executive chairman. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe CV: \u003c/strong\u003eWith Brewer, Walgreens is getting a retail vet with a reputation for investing in digital operations.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eShe joined Starbucks after a five-year stint as the head of Walmart-owned Sam’s Club.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBefore that, Brewer worked at Kimberly-Clark, the consumer goods giant. Fun fact: She started there as a chemist. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBrewer is a big loss for Starbucks, which was also forced to replace its CFO this month. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eBrewer is entering a “plz fix” situation at Walgreens. With the coronavirus taking a sledgehammer to profits, the drugstore chain’s stock \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/walgreens-to-name-starbucks-executive-roz-brewer-as-ceo-11611700794?mod=hp_lead_pos4\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efell 29.4%\u003c/a\u003e last year...even as the broader Dow index gained 7.3%.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nFinking Green\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn his highly anticipated \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/26/business/dealbook/larry-fink-letter-blackrock-climate.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannual letter\u003c/a\u003e to CEOs, BlackRock chief Larry Fink called on businesses to reach net-zero emissions by 2050 and do their part to keep global warming in check. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFink can't technically make companies do anything. But like a parent who controls your allowance (in this case, almost $9 trillion in assets), he effectively can. And he has before:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn 2018, Fink wrote that profit isn't everything and companies need to think about their social impact.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIn 2020, he called for \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/01/14/investors-tough-passive-aggressive?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eprioritizing sustainability\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e and committed BlackRock to factoring climate risks into investment decisions. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUnder the latest directive, BlackRock will create a \"temperature alignment metric\" to assess funds. Like calorie counts on a menu, the goal nudges investors into (environmentally) healthier decisions, DealBook writes.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIf companies don't take the carrot, they may meet Fink's stick. Last year, BlackRock put 191 businesses on a watch list and voted against 64 directors and 69 companies for climate-related reasons. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Fink would argue there's a better reason to play along: \"The more your firms are seen to embrace the climate transition and the opportunities it brings, the more the market will reward your firms with higher valuations.\" \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eEvery Wednesday, we’re going to take a reader-submitted question about business and the economy and do our best to answer it. \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/J0EH3zf3?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAsk your question here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFrom Miles in Little Rock: \u003c/strong\u003eWhy is the stock market at a record while the economy is tanking? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe Brew’s answer: \u003c/strong\u003eHi Miles, it can definitely be disorienting to see the stock market soaring to all-time highs while millions of Americans are out of work because of the pandemic. Here are four possible explanations for the split screen we’re seeing on Wall Street and Main Street.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe stock market is future-looking. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eStock prices reflect investors’ expectations of how companies will perform not now but later—for example, Tesla is worth more than many automakers \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003ecombined\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e because of its long-term growth potential. A roaring stock market means investors are betting on a healthy economic recovery.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe stock market is dominated by huge companies. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd many of these huge companies, such as Amazon, Walmart, and Microsoft, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003ebenefited\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e financially from the pandemic.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe economy isn’t as bad as we think. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome sectors of the economy, such as manufacturing and the housing market, are posting their best performances in more than a decade. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe stock market could also be wrong. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eA number of prominent investors say the stock market is all discombobulated because of the historic stimulus measures deployed by the government.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003eHope that helps!
